title-group.article-title: Conformation-gated binding underlies kinetic asymmetry and negative cooperativity in ATP:cob(I)alamin adenosyltransferase

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Chemistry, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77204, USA
2Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, USA
3Department of Chemistry, William Jewell College, Liberty, MO 64068, USA
4Department of Biological Chemistry, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA

fn.p: P.C. and T.-Y.C. designed research and directed the earlier (P.C.) and later (T.-Y.C.) phases of research. M.L. and R.B. designed plasmids for protein expression and provided some of the purified recombinant protein used in this research. G.Y., M.P., A.M.K., A.G.S., and M.L. performed experiments. G.Y. and M.P. contributed new analytical tools. G.Y., M.P., P.C., and T.-Y.C. analyzed data. G.Y., M.P., R.B., P.C., and T.-Y.C. wrote the paper.

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/).

abstract.title: SUMMARY
abstract.p: Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is a high-value yet scarce cofactor critical for metabolic homeostasis, necessitating efficient handling mechanisms. ATP:cob(I)alamin adenosyltransferase (MMAB) plays a central role in synthesizing, delivering, and repairing 5′-deoxyadenosylcobalamin (AdoCbl), but the kinetic mechanisms regulating this process, including negative cooperativity, remain unclear. Using single-molecule relative fluorescence spectroscopy, we reveal that conformation-gated binding mechanism, involving a required structural rearrangement prior to the first cofactor association, dictates MMAB’s interaction kinetics. This mechanism slows the association of a second AdoCbl, resulting in strong negative cooperativity, favoring the singly bound state, and optimizing AdoCbl handling. This gating mechanism, supported by direct observation of a kinetic intermediate, also contributes to MMAB’s preferential handling of AdoCbl over hydroxocobalamin, highlighting MMAB’s effective cofactor utilization, supporting bacterial survival in nutrient-limited environments. Furthermore, our approach offers a platform to study cofactor interactions, including cobalamin sensing and gene regulation, shedding light on bacterial adaptation to nutrient fluctuations.

abstract.title: In brief
abstract.p: Yan et al. use single-molecule fluorescence to reveal how MMAB captures vitamin B12 efficiently by requiring a conformational change before binding and limiting further binding. This mechanism explains negative cooperativity and optimizes cofactor handling during metabolic processes.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Vitamin B12, or cobalamin, is a high-value cofactor for bacterial and mammalian physiology that is trafficked by a network of chaperones that ensure its proper intracellular handling and targeting.1–4 Within this network, ATP:cob(I)alamin adenosyltransferase (MMAB or ATR) synthesizes 5′-deoxyadenosylcobalamin (AdoCbl) in situ (Figure 1, step 1). In the absence of apo-methylmalonyl-coenzyme A (CoA) mutase (MMUT or MCM, Figure 1, step 2), AdoCbl and triphosphate (PPPi) can dissociate directly from MMAB, leading to potential wastage of a valuable cofactor. To minimize AdoCbl dissociation, MMAB initiates a homolytic reaction, forming cob(II)alamin that has a higher affinity for MMAB and leading to cofactor sequestration instead. However, air oxidation of cob(II)alamin produces hydroxocobalamin (OHCbl), which then dissociates from MMAB.5–7 MMAB loads AdoCbl directly onto apo-MMUT to generate holo-MMUT (Figure 1, step 3), which catalyzes the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA (Figure 1, step 4), replenishing the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle and supporting energy metabolism.2,3,5,6,8–10

MMAB is a homotrimer and exhibits negative cooperativity, whereby association of the first AdoCbl molecule decreases affinity for the second (typically reflected by much smaller subsequent binding affinity than the first one, KD2>KD1). The D180X truncation, corresponding to a clinical variant of human MMAB, leads to loss of negative cooperativity and inefficient cofactor transfer.11–14 Crystallographic analyses of MMAB have captured multiple conformational states, particularly in the mobile loop regions, suggesting that these structural elements may play a key role in mediating conformational transitions during cobalamin binding and transfer.7 These findings suggest a potential link between structural flexibility and negative cooperativity, motivating elucidation of the kinetic basis of this regulatory mechanism. Understanding the specific association and dissociation rate constants governing each binding step is key to unraveling how this change in affinity arises.

Investigating the kinetic properties underlying the interaction between MMAB and the derivatives of B12 at the ensemble level poses several challenges. The dynamic nature of these interactions can obscure transient states or rare conformations essential for enzyme function.15–17 Additionally, the homotrimeric architecture of MMAB complicates the measurement of cofactor stoichiometry. Traditional ensemble techniques like isothermal titration calorimetry, while informative, do not capture the full scope of these rapid and cooperative interactions.18,19 To obtain a clearer, high-resolution view of kinetic behavior, more advanced methods such as single-molecule techniques20–23 and/or advanced computational simulations24–26 are required.

In this study, we investigated MMAB from Methylobacterium extorquens, a model organism for studying bacterial B12 metabolism, using a single-molecule relative fluorescence (SRF) approach. The instability of the native substrate, 5-coordinate cob(II)alamin, which is highly prone to air oxidation,27,28 complicates direct kinetic analysis under aerobic conditions. We therefore used hydroxocobalamin (OHCbl) as a stable surrogate, alongside the product, AdoCbl. While OHCbl is 6-coordinate in solution, it is expected to adopt a 5-coordinate, “base-off” state upon binding to MMAB in the absence of the cosubstrate ATP, similar to the physiological substrate. This structural similarity in the bound state, combined with previous reports demonstrating negative cooperativity for OHCbl with MMAB,6,11 supports its use in our mechanistic study. The SRF intensities enabled us to distinguish between MMAB states with 0–2 bound B12 equivalents and to determine the transition times between these states. We find that a two-step kinetic model, derived from dwell-time distributions, effectively describes the interaction of MMAB with AdoCbl and OHCbl. Our kinetic model indicates that MMAB undergoes a conformational change before binding AdoCbl or OHCbl. The data reveal that the faster association of the first B12 moiety, rather than faster dissociation of the second B12 moiety, is responsible for the observed negative cooperativity. The model further suggests that loss of negative cooperativity and impaired cofactor handling of the D180X MMAB variant could be due to a disruption of this association mechanism. These findings offer a clearer understanding of the kinetic mechanisms governing AdoCbl binding to and release from MMAB.

sec.title: SRF trajectories visualize MMAB-AdoCbl interactions
sec.p: The UV-visible absorption of AdoCbl makes it a strong fluorescence quencher (Figure 2A), enabling the investigation of MMAB-AdoCbl interactions using fluorescence microscopy. To streamline the dye-labeling procedure and avoid complications, the cysteines in MMAB, which are not conserved, were converted to serine, yielding a Cys-less variant. In this background, Ser99 and Ser169 were subsequently mutated to cysteine for labeling (methods). We selected trimeric MMAB with a single equivalent of Alexa Fluor 555 dye (Alexa 555) at Cys99 to test the AdoCbl concentration-dependent fluorescence at the ensemble level (methods). The fluorescence intensity decreased with increasing AdoCbl concentration (Figure 2B), indicating that AdoCbl binding could be probed by fluorescence quenching. To directly visualize MMAB-AdoCbl interaction events in real time, we conducted Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET)-based SRF imaging (methods). We immobilized the Alexa 555-labeled MMAB on a glass slide, flowed AdoCbl solutions into the imaging chamber, and detected single-molecule fluorescence. The dwell times of the intensity fluctuations report on the MMAB-AdoCbl interaction kinetics.

To differentiate unbound MMABU, singly bound MMABS, and doubly bound MMABD MMAB, we carefully removed the complications of inhomogeneous laser excitation and generated SRF trajectories (methods). Figure 2C shows the single-molecule fluorescence image without AdoCbl. Each bright spot represents a single MMABU and maintains a relatively stable intensity over time (Figure 2D). However, inhomogeneous laser excitation results in fluorescence signals with various intensities, even though all MMAB exist in an unbound state. To address this complication, we normalized each fluorescence signal of MMABU by its own average intensity to generate the SRF dataset (Figures 2E–2G). The SRF approach allows a direct combination and comparison of all fluorescence trajectories from different protein molecules. Since the quenching efficiency is directly related to the number of AdoCbl bound to MMAB, the SRF approach allows the differentiation of MMABU,MMABS, and MMABD.

sec.title: SRF states reveal various MMAB-AdoCbl binding configurations
sec.p: Figure 3A shows SRF trajectories reporting interactions between MMAB and AdoCbl with different AdoCbl concentrations. At each concentration, we compiled >200 SRF trajectories to generate normalized histograms, probability density functions (PDFs) that describe the relative occupancy of different fluorescence states. These PDFs can be modeled as a combination of high (FH≈1.0), middle (FM≈0.77), and low (FL≈0.1) fluorescence states (Figure 3B). We globally fit the PDFs using a three-state Gaussian model. The center position and width of each Gaussian distribution were shared across all concentrations while allowing the relative populations of the three states to float. As AdoCbl increased from 0 to 20 μM, the FH population decreased and shifted toward FM while the FL population grew continuously. A clear FM peak appeared when AdoCbl was >40 μM, and the FL peak gradually saturated. Thus, while FH decreases, FM and FL increased and approached saturating populations (Note S1 and Figure S4C).

Using AdoCbl-dependent populations, we assigned SRF states to MMAB binding stoichiometries. Labeling MMAB with a single Alexa 555 broke its trilateral symmetry and resulted in different binding configurations. Figure 3C summarizes all possible MMAB binding configurations. In the absence of AdoCbl, the histogram shows a single state with FH≈1.0 (Figure 3B, top), indicating that only MMABU contributed to the FH state (Figure 3C, top left). At 60 μM AdoCbl, a saturating concentration, MMAB exists predominantly in the doubly bound form, MMABD, giving three binding configurations. The ratio of FM to FL was ~2:1 (Figure 3B, bottom), indicating that two and one MMABD contributed to FM and FL states, respectively. Since the SRF intensity is dependent on the distance between the label and bound AdoCbl, we assigned the MMABD with two AdoCbl bound in the closest positions to the FL state and the other two to the FM state (Figure 3C, box 1). This assignment also indicates that the quenching efficiency of AdoCbl bound to the farthest site is insignificant. Application of this concept to the singly bound case led to the assignment of the MMABS species in the FH and FM states in a 1:2 ratio (Figure 3C, box 2). These assignments were also supported by another MMAB construct labeled at Cys169 (Note S1). From the above analysis, we associated FH with MMABU+1/3MMABS,FM with 2/3 MMABS+2/3MMABD, and FL state with 1/3MMABD.

sec.title: Dwell-time analysis reveals an intermediate species and a kinetic model for MMAB-AdoCbl interactions
sec.p: Most AdoCbl-induced transitions occur between FH and FM or FM and FL, while direct transitions between FH and FL states are occasionally observed (~5%). Importantly, the experimentally observed rate of these direct FH-to-FL transitions exhibits an approximately linear or saturating dependence on [AdoCbl] (Figure S6D). This linear (not quadratic) concentration dependence directly indicates that MMABD forms primarily through two sequential AdoCbl bindings and that simultaneous binding and unbinding of two AdoCbl is rare and thus not considered further. To quantify interaction kinetics, SRF trajectories were first analyzed using the empirical Bayes hidden Markov model analysis software, ebFRET, to generate transition trajectories (solid lines in Figure 3A; methods).29–31 We extracted transition dwell times from trajectories and generated the PDFs of dwell times.

τHM is the microscopic dwell time in FH before transitioning to the FM state. The overall average transition rate, <τHM>-1, increased with increasing AdoCbl concentrations (Figure 4A). The apparent steeper slope at lower concentrations visually suggests faster initial binding. To obtain a robust conclusion, we further performed full dwell-time analysis of our single-molecule data across all concentrations. Notably, the microscopic dwell-time distribution (τHM) exhibits a clear exponential rise-and-decay pattern at lower AdoCbl concentrations (<20 μM, Figures 4B [left four panels] and S6C), indicating the presence of a concentration-independent kinetic intermediate state in the FH state.32,33 This rise-and-decay feature vanishes at high AdoCbl concentrations (40 μM and 60 μM), suggesting that this intermediate is primarily associated with the MMABU-to-MMABS transitions. We posit this intermediate as a conformational change in MMABU instead of MMABS in the FH state. Using a single-molecule interaction simulation (SMIS, Note S2),24 we confirmed that MMAB undergoes a conformational change (i.e., the transition from MMABU1 to MMABU2) before the first AdoCbl binds.

On the other hand, τLM captures the transitions from the FL to the FM state and describes AdoCbl unbinding from the MMABD. The <τLM>-1 (Figure 4C) and PDFLM (Figure 4D) remain the same across all AdoCbl concentrations. The dose-independent rates indicate that AdoCbl dissociates from MMABD via a typical unimolecular mechanism. τML and τMH, the microscopic dwell times of the FM state before respectively transitioning to the FL and FH states, contain mixed AdoCbl binding and unbinding information for MMABS and MMABD. Both <τML>-1 and <τMH>-1 reveal the overall rates of all kinetic processes that start from the FM state, which is supported by the fact that both <τML>-1 and <τMH>-1 show identical AdoCbl dependence (Figure 4E). The ratio of the number of transition events for the τML and τMH process (i.e., #ML/#MH) increases linearly with AdoCbl (Figure 4F). Since the association rate of AdoCbl to MMAB is expected to be scaled linearly with AdoCbl, the #ML/#MH data indicate that AdoCbl dissociates from MMABS also occurs through a unimolecular mechanism.

Based on the kinetic data described above, we developed a minimal model to explain the AdoCbl binding and dissociation pathways. The model accounts for (1) a required conformational gating step prior to the first binding event, (2) the dose dependence of the binding transitions, and (3) a unimolecular dissociation process from both binding sites. Using SMIS analysis, we compared alternative dissociation routes and found that only the pathway where AdoCbl unbinding from MMABS leads to the specific unbound state MMABU1 consistently fit all dwell-time distributions (Note S3). This kinetic framework is summarized in Figure 4G.

sec.title: The kinetic model describes the complex kinetics of MMAB-AdoCbl interactions
sec.p: Applying the MMAB-AdoCbl binding configurations (Figure 3C) to a minimal kinetic model (Figure 4G) resulted in a fairly complex system (Figure 5A), precluding the feasibility of deriving an analytical solution for most dwell-time PDFs (i.e., fHM(τ), fML(τ), and fMH(τ)). fLM(τ) is the only exception, because it only describes the unbinding step for MMABD(fLM(τ)=kr2×e-kr2t). Fitting the distributions of τLM with fLM(τ) crossing all AdoCbl concentrations revealed the dissociation rate constants kr2 (Figure 5B). The derivation of either fHM(τ), fMH(τ), or fML(τ) was too complicated due to the ill-defined ratio of the initial species (i.e., FH and FM states). To circumvent this challenge, we defined and extracted two additional dwell times, τLMH and τLML. τLMH and τLML represent the subsets of τMH and τML, respectively, which include only the dwell time starting from the FL state. This selection results in τLMH and τLML having a well-defined initial state (i.e., MMABS in the FM state, Figure 5A) and enables derivations of fLML(τ) and fLMH(τ) (methods). The global fitting of PDFLML and PDFLMH with fLML(τ) and fLMH(τ) (Figure 5C) yielded kf2 and kr1. To quantify k1i,k-1i, and k1, we used SMIS to test a large range of k1i,k-1i, and k1 and obtained a solution set that satisfactorily described our data (Figure 5D).24 Based on the kinetic model, we derived the unbinding equilibrium constants KD1 and KD2 (methods): (Equation 1)KD1=kr1kf1=kr1k1k1i+kr1k1i+k-1i, (Equation 2)KD2=kr2kf2.

kf1 and kr1 represent the overall forward association and reverse dissociation rate constants for transitions between MMABU and MMABS, while kf2 and kr2 are for transitions between MMABS and MMABD. Table 1 summarizes the extracted rate constants and reports values for KD1=5.6±2.9μM and KD2=41.7±13.9μM. Notably, our experimentally determined KD2/KD1 ratio (~7-fold) significantly exceeds the 3.3-fold ratio predicted by statistical considerations for a trimeric protein exhibiting no cooperativity (see Note S4 for detailed derivation), clearly indicating negative cooperativity.

sec.title: HOCbl interacts with MMAB using a kinetic model similar to that of AdoCbl
sec.p: HOCbl binding to MMAB showed stronger quenching than AdoCbl because of its larger FRET spectral overlap with the Alexa dye (Figure 2A). SRF intensity histograms identified three fluorescence states (Figure 6A), which were used to determine the HOCbl-dependent populations (Figure 6B) and assign possible binding configurations (Figure 6C). The difference in the distribution of MMAB conformers between AdoCbl and OHCbl is attributed to their distinct fluorescence quenching efficiencies, primarily driven by differences in spectral overlap with Alexa 555. For AdoCbl, distance-dependent quenching efficiency results in fewer detectable distinct conformers, with distant-bound forms indistinguishable from singly bound states. Conversely, OHCbl’s stronger and more uniform quenching efficiency across all binding sites causes singly bound MMAB forms to collectively shift into a single moderate-SRF state (FM), while all doubly bound conformers are distinctly observed in the low-SRF state (FM, Notes S1 and S5).

We note that our highest tested concentration for OHCbl was 80 μM, which is below the previously reported KD (~200 μM). However, our single-molecule approach uniquely allows robust characterization of kinetic parameters and intermediate conformational states at subsaturating concentrations. Such conditions ensure dynamic sampling of the unbound state (FH), which serves as an essential internal reference for quantifying relative fluorescence and observing the full kinetic cycle. Therefore, extending beyond 80 μM would provide limited additional mechanistic insight and was not pursued.

By carefully analyzing the dwell-time distributions (Figure 6D), we proposed a similar minimal kinetic model to describe the MMAB-HOCbl interactions (Figure 6E and Note S6). MMAB also required a conformational change (MMABU1 to MMABU3) to bind the first equivalent of HOCbl (Figure 6E). The extracted conformational change rate constants k1i and k-1i of OHCbl binding (2.8 s−1 and 4.0 s−1) are distinct from the ones observed during AdoCbl binding (8.4 s−1 and 2.0 s−1). This suggests that unbound MMAB exists in a dynamic equilibrium of multiple conformations. The different kinetics arise because AdoCbl and OHCbl preferentially select different pre-existing protein conformations (MMABU2 and MMABU3, respectively) for their binding pathways. The existence of the MMABU3 state highlights MMAB’s flexible conformational landscape and supports a general conformation-gated mechanism adapted for different cobalamin derivatives.

sec.title: Key findings from AdoCbl and OHCbl binding analyses
sec.p: Our single-molecule kinetic analysis revealed that MMAB binds AdoCbl primarily via a two-step mechanism. Rare direct transitions between FH and FL states, along with a distinct rise-and-decay pattern in the τHM dwell-time distribution, support the existence of a required conformational intermediate prior to the first binding event. This implies that unbound MMAB samples at least two conformational states, consistent with previous crystallographic data. We also observed that AdoCbl dissociation from both the singly and doubly bound states follows a unimolecular mechanism, reflected by dose-independent <τLM>-1 values and the linear increase of #ML/#MH with concentration, respectively. Modeling of the dissociation pathway suggests that AdoCbl unbinding from MMABD returns MMAB to the singly bound MMABS state, which in turn can relax to a specific unbound conformation (MMABU1). In parallel, OHCbl binding exhibited similar overall kinetics, including the presence of a pre-binding conformational intermediate and negative cooperativity. However, differences in fluorescence quenching and intermediate conformer distributions underscore ligand-specific adaptations in MMAB’s conformational landscape. These observations collectively support a unified conformation-gated binding model, finely tuned by the structure of the cofactor.

sec.title: Kinetic model describes ensemble results
sec.p: Using the SRF assay, we described a two-step kinetic model and quantified the kinetic and thermodynamic constants for interactions between MMAB and cobalamin. Before MMAB binds the first equivalent of cobalamin, it must adopt a specific conformation (MMABU2 and MMABU3). Association of the first cobalamin moiety slows down binding of the second, leading to negative cooperativity. Dissociation of cobalamin from MMAB follows a unimolecular pathway and is independent of cobalamin concentration. Using the extracted rate constants (Table 1) and kinetic model (Figures 4G and 6E), we simulated the stopped-flow differential absorption traces for AdoCbl binding to apo-MMAB (Note S7), which captured the AdoCbl dependence of differential ensemble absorption spectra reported previously,6 thus validating our model.

sec.title: D180X loses negative cooperativity due to the reduced kf for the first substrate
sec.p: The D180X truncation mutant, a clinically relevant variant, abolishes negative cooperativity and significantly reduces AdoCbl binding and catalytic activity.11 Although we did not examine D180X using single-molecule methods due to its instability and tendency to aggregate, previously reported ensemble studies show a substantial increase in KM and a decrease in kcat. These biochemical defects are consistent with impaired initial substrate binding. Our kinetic model attributes negative cooperativity to a high kf1, enabled by a conformational gating mechanism that facilitates efficient binding of the first substrate equivalent. In wild-type MMAB, this gating allows a faster kf1 relative to kf2. Our data rule out differences in dissociation rate constants as the basis for cooperativity, as the values for kr1 and kr2 were comparable between binding events (Table 1). Therefore, loss of gating, as likely occurs in D180X, would reduce kf1, weakening initial substrate binding, slowing turnover, and increasing KD. This mechanism aligns with the reported ~2-fold higher KM, ~3-fold lower kcat, and ~400-fold reduction in AdoCbl affinity in D180X.

sec.title: Biological implications of the kinetic model
sec.p: Since the intracellular concentration of B12 derivatives is relatively low (nM to low μM), efficient substrate capture is important for the catalytic efficiency of ATR. A larger kf for binding at the first site allows ATR to rapidly bind cob(II)alamin and convert it to AdoCbl, facilitating cofactor synthesis under substrate-limited conditions. Previous studies have shown that when MMAB is doubly loaded, ATP selectively ejects AdoCbl from the weaker-binding second site while retaining the tightly bound AdoCbl at the first site.34 This selective ejection minimizes premature cofactor loss into solution and results in MMAB retaining one AdoCbl equivalent, potentially serving as a functional reserve. Negative cooperativity slows down the binding of a second equivalent of AdoCbl, which contributes to disfavoring back transfer of the cofactor from MMUT to MMAB. If both sites were to bind cob(II)alamin and convert it to AdoCbl at similar rates, the balance between cofactor synthesis and transfer could be disrupted, increasing the likelihood of premature AdoCbl release into solution. Thus, the combination of negative cooperativity and ATP-driven AdoCbl transfer appears to represent a solution for balancing cob(II)alamin availability with the AdoCbl demand.

sec.title: Broader applicability of SRF
sec.p: Our SRF approach revealed the dynamic interactions and binding kinetics of MMAB with B12 derivatives and provided insights into the basic mechanism of cofactor handling by MMAB. The SRF approach holds the potential for broader applications, for example to study the interaction between riboswitches and cobalamin derivatives,35–37 offering a powerful tool for probing the regulatory mechanisms governing cobalamin sensing and gene regulation in bacterial systems.

sec.title: Protein purification and labeling
sec.p: To visualize MMAB through a fluorescence microscope, we used mutagenesis to introduce a unique cysteine for fluorescent probe labeling. The Methylobacterium extorquens MMAB contains two natural non-conserved cysteines (C64 and C154) in each subunit. Both cysteines are less surface exposed and, thus, not ideal for serving as labeling sites. To avoid possible complications in the dye-labeling procedure, we mutated these two cysteines to serine to create a Cys-less MMAB. We then identified S99 and S169 in two-loop regions to introduce cysteine for labeling (Figure S1A). These two sites are non-conserved, solvent exposed, do not participate in H bonding to stabilize the protein structure, and are distant from the AdoCbl binding sites. Both MMAB variants were active in catalyzing AdoCbl synthesis and showed no precipitation at room temperature for >2 h (Table S1). S99C MMAB maintained 94% catalytic activity and, like wild-type MMAB, released only one equivalent of AdoCbl into solution. In contrast, S169C MMAB exhibited 41% of wild-type activity while also releasing only one equivalent of AdoCbl. For the remainder of the study, we focused on S99C MMAB. The MMAB mutants were cloned in a pET28 vector and overexpressed in E. coli BL21 (DE3), growing in 20 g/L LB medium, containing 30 mg/L kanamycin and 34 mg/L chloramphenicol or 0.05 mg/mL kanamycin at 37°C. After OD600nm reached 0.6, 1 mM isopropyl β-D-1-thiogalactopyranoside (IPTG) was added to the solution to induce expression for 4 h. Cells were then centrifuged and resuspended in buffer 1 (50 mM sodium phosphate buffer [pH 8.0] containing 0.3 M KCl, 20 mM imidazole, 0.1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride [PMSF], and 5% glycerol), after which 100 mg of lysozyme was added and stirring continued at 4°C for 30 min. Cells were sonicated, and the supernatant was collected following centrifugation to remove cell debris. The final supernatant was passed through a 0.2-μm syringe filter and purified by high-performance liquid chromatography using a His-trap column as described previously.11

The MMAB variants were labeled with Alexa 555 using maleimide chemistry. Before labeling, MMAB was reduced by mixing with 5 μL of tris(2-carboxyethyl)phosphine hydrochloride (TCEP) (200 mM) and 200 μL of MMAB (0.45 mM) in buffer 1 to achieve final concentrations of 4.88 mM and 0.44 mM, respectively. The solution was incubated at 4°C overnight. The Alexa 555-maleimide/Bio-PEG-maleimide solution was prepared by mixing 13.3 μL of Alexa 555 in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) (30 mM) with 3.2 μL of Bio-PEG-maleimide in DMSO (250 mM). Reduced MMAB (205 μL, 0.44 mM) was mixed with 4 μL of Alexa 555-maleimide/Bio-PEG-maleimide mixture in a final volume of 209 μL. The mixture was flushed with N2 for 1 min to exclude O2 and incubated at room temperature for 1.5 h or overnight at 4°C. The labeling reaction was performed in darkness to protect the fluorescent dye Alexa 555. Labeled MMAB was passed through a Superdex peptide column (GE Healthcare, Superdex Peptide 10/300 GL) and Mono Q anion column (GE Healthcare, Tricorn Mono Q 5/50 GL) with elution buffer (50 mM sodium phosphate buffer [pH 8.0] containing 0.3 M KCl, 150 mM imidazole, 0.1 mM PMSF, and 5% glycerol) to obtain Alexa 555-labeled MMAB, which was confirmed by SDS-PAGE gel (Figure S1B).

sec.title: Ensemble fluorescence quenching assay
sec.p: To validate that the interactions between dye-labeled MMAB and cobalamin indeed lead to a fluorescence intensity decrease, we quantified the fluorescence intensity of MMAB solutions with different cobalamin concentrations. A control experiment (solution with dye instead of dye-labeled MMAB) was performed in parallel to ensure the quenching was indeed due to MMAB-cobalamin interaction rather than random collisions between the dye and cobalamin. We labeled the S99C MMAB with an FRET donor dye, Alexa 555 or Cy3, and used AdoCbl as the acceptor. Note that Alexa 555 and Cy3 have very similar emission spectra, with the emission maximum centered around 555 nm (Figure S2A). The rationale for using AdoCbl instead of OHCbl is that AdoCbl has a smaller spectral overlap (i.e., lower quenching efficiency, Figure 1A). We reasoned that if AdoCbl shows significant quenching, this approach was likely to be even more effective for probing MMAB-OHCbl interactions. Figure S2B shows the fluorescent spectrum of 0.5 μM Cy3-labeled S99C MMAB mixed with AdoCbl, (0–6 μM). Due to the interaction of the donor MMAB-Cy3 and the acceptor AdoCbl, the fluorescent signal decreases with increasing AdoCbl concentrations and reaches ~30% of the initial intensity at [AdoCbl] = 6 μM. In contrast, the Cy3 control experiment shows that the fluorescent spectrum of 0.5 μM Cy3 mixed still maintains ~80% of the initial intensity. The result from the control experiment indicates that random collisions between Cy3 and AdoCbl decrease the fluorescent signal only slightly. These results indicate that the fluorescent quenching assay can detect the interaction of MMAB and AdoCbl. We thus applied this concept and investigated the MMAB-cobalamin interactions via a single-molecule fluorescence quenching assay.

sec.title: Single-molecule fluorescence setup
sec.p: Single-molecule relative fluorescence (SRF) experiments were performed on an Olympus IX71 inverted microscope using a prism-type total internal reflection fluorescence (TIRF) configuration. In the excitation path, the 532-nm laser (CrystaLaser) passed a quarter waveplate (Thorlabs AQWP05M-600) to ensure circularly polarized excitation. The laser excited labeled MMAB under TIRF geometry at a power of ~6–7 mW across a 68 × 137 μm2 area. The fluorescent signal from Alexa 555 was collected through a 60×, NA = 1.2, water-immersion objective (Olympus) and filtered by an HQ550LP filter (Chroma) before entering the EMCCD camera (Andor iXon). The image of Alexa 555 fluorescence intensity was obtained using Andor iQ software. The video was acquired with an image integration time of 32 ms, and the typical video length is ~1–2 min. A homemade flow chamber was prepared by fixing a clean coverslip on the clean quartz slide as reported by Joshi et al.38 The surface of the quartz slide was functionalized with biotinylated albumin (Sigma) and neutravidin. The sample containing the labeled MMAB was incubated at ~30 pM for 5–15 min to ensure proper sample density for SRF measurements. AdoCbl and OHCbl solutions with various concentrations (0–80 μM) flow into the flow chamber with a flow velocity of 10 μL/min. A photoprotection system (1 mM Trolox and 10 mM cysteamine) was added into the AdoCbl solution immediately before each experiment to prevent photoblinking and photobleaching of the fluorescent probe.

sec.title: SRF trajectory generation
sec.p: After identifying the single labeled MMAB spots from the fluorescence micrograph, we generated the intensity trajectory by integrating the pixel intensity of a 3 × 3-pixel area from the center of each spot (Figure S3A). Only trajectories that showed a single-step photobleaching event were analyzed. Due to the Gaussian profile of the excitation laser (Figure S3B), spots in the center area show higher intensities than those in the peripheral regions. This intensity heterogeneity prevents direct intensity comparison and limits fluorescence quenching assay usage. To address this issue, we further normalized each intensity trajectory and generated the SRF trajectory for subsequent analysis using home-built MATLAB functions following these steps. (1) We first conducted single-molecule fluorescence microscopy to collect dye-labeled MMAB intensities under cobalamin-free conditions. Without the complication of quencher (i.e., cobalamin), all singly labeled MMAB are expected to have identical intensities. When examining the intensity distribution of these singly labeled MMAB, we observed an excellent agreement with the laser excitation profile. We thus normalized the intensity trajectories by its mean intensity using the data without the photobleaching part and generated the SRF trajectories. (2) To generate the SRF trajectories for [AdoCbl] varying from 2 to 60 μM, we normalized their intensity trajectories with the selected intensity trajectory under AdoCbl-free conditions. We grouped the spot based on its distance to the center of the beam profile. We considered these spots under similar excitation power density and, thus, similar single-molecule intensity. For each target spot, we searched for reference spots in the same group under AdoCbl-free conditions for normalization (Figure S3C). We generated the final SRF trajectory by dividing the target trajectory by the mean intensity of the reference spot (Figure S3D).

sec.title: Dwell-time analysis and ebFRET software usage
sec.p: Microscopic dwell times of each SRF trajectory were obtained using the ebFRET software (http://ebfret.github.io/) with the number of fluorescent states set to 3.30 The ebFRET is a software that uses empirical Bayes hidden Markov model analysis to analyze noisy trajectories and extract the microscopic dwell times. To ensure the ebFRET can robustly extract the dwell times, we compared the ebFRET extracted dwell-time distributions with the ground-truth data. In short, using a 3-state kinetic model with a hidden state in the high state (Figure S5A), we simulated single-molecule trajectories with given rate constants using a home-built software, SMIS.24,39 A random noise was then added onto the simulated trajectories to generate final trajectories that have similar signal-to-noise ratio as the experimental data (Figure S5B). These simulated trajectories were then analyzed with ebFRET to extract the microscopic dwell times. Figure S5B shows the overlay of the simulated (blue curve) and the ebFRET-extracted trajectories (orange curve) and demonstrate that the ebFRET faithfully captures the transitions. More importantly, the extracted dwell-time distributions between states, including τHM,τMH,τML, and τLM (Figure S5C), nicely reproduced the expected ground-truth data, validating the usage of ebFRET to obtain the microscopic dwell times for our experimental data (Figure S5D).

With the extracted microscopic dwell times from the cleaned-up SRF trajectories (Figure S6A), we generated the probability density functions (PDF) of τHM,τMH,τML, and τLM. Considering the first bin is often inaccurate due to limited time resolution, we removed the first bin in all dwell-time histograms.40 We further combined every two bins so that the final time resolution is 60 ms to ensure the histogram is statistically saturated (Figure S6B). Figure S6C summarizes PDFHM,PDFMH,PDFML, and PDFLM with AdoCbl concentration varying from 0 to 60 μM.

sec.title: Derivations of fLMH(τ) and fLML(τ)
sec.p: We derived the analytical expression of the probability density function of dwell time, fLMH(τ) and fLML(τ), using the kinetic model presented in Figure S10. MMAB with different configurations were labeled individually. For example, the MMABS in the FH was labeled as MMABS1, and the remaining MMABS in the FM were labeled as MMABS2 and MMABS3. The two MMABD in the FM were labeled as MMABD1 and MMABD2, and the remaining MMABD in the FL was labeled as MMABD3. Note that the species (1) MMABS2 and MMABS3 and (2) MMABD1 and MMABD2 are two equivalent and undistinguishable pairs in our model. We, therefore, combined each group to simplify the derivations.

To solve fLMH(τ) and fLML(τ), we started with the analytical expression of the probabilities of finding the species MMABS3,PS3(t). We first focused on the steps that involve the transition PS2(t) and PS3(t). The single-molecule rate equations for these steps are (Equation 3)dPS3(t)dt=dPS2(t)dt=12kr2PD1(t)-k2o+kr1PS3(t), (Equation 4)dPD1(t)dt=dPD2(t)dt=12k20PS3(t)-kr2PD1(t), where Pi(t) are the probabilities of finding the species (i=S2,S3,D2,D3) in the corresponding states at time t. Note that kf20 (i.e., kf2[S]) is treated as pseudo-first-order rate constant and Pi′(t) is equal to dPi(t)/dt. We first applied Laplace transform to Equations 3 and 4: (Equation 5)ℒPS3′(t)=12kr2ℒPD1(t)-kf20+kr1ℒPS3(t), (Equation 6)ℒPD1′(t)=12kf20ℒPS3(t)-kr2ℒPD1(t).

Each ℒPi′(t) in Equations S8 and S9 were equal to sℒPi(t)-Pi(0). Since we defined all transitions starting from MMABS2 or MMABS3, we obtained the following boundary conditions: PS3(0)=PS3(0)=0.5,PD1(0)=PD2(0)=0. By substituting ℒPi′(t) with sℒPi(t)-Pi(0) in Equation 5 and Equation 6 and replacing Pi(0) with values specified in the boundary conditions, we expressed ℒPi′(t) as (Equation 7)s+kf20+kr1ℒPS3(t)-0.5=12kr2ℒPD1t, (Equation 8)ℒPD1(t)=12kf20ℒPS3(t)/s+kr2.
Substituting ℒPD1(t) in Equation 7 using Equation 8, we can express ℒPS3(t) with rate constants as (Equation 9)ℒPS3(t)=b+kr2214kf20kr2-b+kr2b+kf20+kr2.

To derive the fLMH(τ) in the two-state kinetic model, we focused on the steps involved in the transition from MMABS2 or MMABS3→MMABU1 and MMABD1 or MMABD2→MMABS1 (Figure S10). The single-molecule rate equations for these steps are (Equation 10)dPU1(t)dt=kr1PS3(t)+kr1PS2(t)=2kr1PS3(t), (Equation 11)dPS1(t)dt=12kr2PD1(t)+12kr2PD2(t)=kr2PD1(t).

Here, the initial conditions are PU1(0)=0 and PS1(0)=0 at t=0. Taking the Laplace transform of Equation 10 and Equation 11, we obtained (Equation 12)ℒPU1′(t)=2kr1ℒPS3(t), (Equation 13)ℒPS1′(t)=kr2ℒPD1(t).
ℒPD1(t) in Equation 13 was further replaced by Equation 8, which resulted in a new ℒPS1′(t) expressed as a function of ℒPS3(t): (Equation 14)ℒPS1′(t)=kr2kf20ℒPS3(t)2s+kr2.

τLMH is the time needed to complete steps involving kf2,kr1, and kr2. The probability of finding a particular τ is equal to the probability for the switch from MMABS2 or MMABS3→MMABU and MMABD1 or MMABD2→MMABS1 state between t=τ and τ+Δτ. Mathematically, this probability is equal to ΔPS1(τ)+ΔPU1(τ). In the limit of infinitesimal Δτ, the probability density function of dwell time τLMH,fLMH(t), was obtained from (Equation 15)fLMHt=dPS1tdt+dPU1tdt=PS1′t+PU1′t.
Taking the Laplace transform of Equation 15, we obtained (Equation 16)ℒfLMH(t)=ℒPS1′(t)+PU1′(t)=ℒPS1′(t)+ℒPU1′(t).

Substituting the ℒPS1′(t) and ℒPU1′(t) in Equation 16 with Equation 12 and Equation 14; replacing ℒPS3(t) using Equation 9, we got (Equation 17)ℒfLMH(t)=kr1s+14kf20kr2+kr1kr2s2+kf20+kr1+kr2s+34kf20kr2+kr1kr2.

Inverse Laplace transform of Equation 17 gave the probability density function of dwell time, fLMH(τ): (Equation 18)fLMH(τ)=4kr1b+a+kr2+kf20kr18ae(b+a)τ-4kr1b-a+kr2+kf20kr18aeb-aτ, where a=12kf202+kr12+kr22+2kf20kr1-kf20kr2-2kr1kr2 =b2-34kf20kr2-kr1kr2 and b=-12kf20+kr1+kr2.

To derive the fLML(τ) in the two-state kinetic model, we focused on the steps involved in the transition to MMABD (Figure S10). The single-molecule rate equation for these steps is (Equation 19)dPD3(t)dt=12kf20PS2(t)+12kf20PS3(t)=kf20PS3(t).
Here, the initial condition is PD3(0)=0 at t=0. Taking the Laplace transform of Equation 19, we obtained (Equation 20)ℒPD3′(t)=k20ℒPS3(t).

τLML is the time needed to complete steps involving kf2,kr1,and kr2. The probability of finding a particular τ is equal to the probability for the switch from MMABS3 or MMABS3→MMABD3 between t=τ and τ+Δτ. Mathematically, this probability is equal to ΔPD3(τ). In the limit of infinitesimal Δτ, the probability density function of dwell time τLML,fLML(t), was obtained from (Equation 21)fLMLτ=dPD3τdτ=PD3′τ.
Taking the Laplace transform of Equation 21, we obtained (Equation 22)ℒfLML(τ)=ℒPD3′(τ)
Substituting the ℒPD3′(τ) in Equation 22 with Equation 20; replacing ℒPS3(t) using Equation 9, we got (Equation 23)ℒfLML(τ)=12kf20s+kr2s2+kf20+kr1+kr2s+34kf20kr2+kr1kr2.

Inverse Laplace transform of Equation 23 gave the probability density function of dwell time, fLML(τ): (Equation 24)fLML(τ)=kf204ab+a+kr2e(b+a)τ-b-a+kr2e(b-a)τ, where a and b are defined the same as in Equation 18. Finally, the analytical probability density functions, fLML(τ) and fLMH(τ), were used to globally fit the distributions of τLML and τLMH by MATLAB and extracted out the rate constants kf2,kr1, and kr2.

sec.title: Derivations of KD1 and KD2
sec.p: Using the proposed kinetic model, we derived the analytical solution of the equilibrium dissociation constants for MMABS and MMABD from the population relationship. Assuming the system is under dynamic equilibrium condition, the populations of MMABU1(PU1),MMABU2(PU2),MMABS(PS), and MMABD(PD) can be associated with rate constants and [AdoCbl] (L) through the following equations: (Equation 25)kr1PS+k-1iPU2=k1iPU1, (Equation 26)k1LPU2+kr2PD=kr1+k2LPS, (Equation 27)kf2LPS=kr2PD, (Equation 28)k1iPU1=k1L+k-1iPU2, (Equation 29)PU1+PS+PD+PU2=1.

By solving Equations 25, 26, 27, 28, and 29, we expressed the populations of these species as a function of rate constants as follows: (Equation 30)PU1=k1L+k-1ikr1kr2C, (Equation 31)PS=k1ik1kr2LC, (Equation 32)PD=k1ik1kf2L2C, (Equation 33)PU2=k1ikr1kr2C, where C=k1ikr1kr2+kr1kr2k-1i+k1L+k1ik1Lkr2+k2L.

We then defined the fractional occupancy Ω(L) as the population of the bound species over the population of all species that are involved in the equilibrium, so we can get the expression of the first binding fractional occupancy Ω1(L) and the second binding fractional occupancy Ω2(L) as follows: (Equation 34)Ω1L=PSPU1+PU2+PS, (Equation 35)Ω2L=PDPS+PD.
Substituting PU1,PS,PD, and PU2 in Equations 34 and 35 with Equations 30, 31, 32, and 33 we obtained (Equation 36)Ω1L=k1ik1Lkr1k-1i+k1L+k1ikr1+k1L, (Equation 37)Ω2L=kf2Lkf2L+kr2.
We then defined the KD1 and KD2 by the concentration of AdoCbl at which the Ω1(L)=12×Ω1,max(L) and Ω2(L)=12×Ω2,max(L), respectively: (Equation 38)KD1=kr1k1i+k-1ik1k1i+kr1, (Equation 39)KD2=kr2kf2.

Equations 38 and 39 can be expressed in terms of the overall forward (i.e., kf1 and kf2) and reverse rate constants (i.e., kr1 and kr2) where kf1=k1k1i+kr1/k1i+k-1i: (Equation 40)KD1=kr1k1i+k-1ikf1=kr1k1k1i+kr1/k1i+k-1i, (Equation 41)KD2=kr2kf2.

Using the rate constants listed in Table 1, we estimate the KD1, Ado = 5.6 ± 2.9 μM and KD2,Ado=41.7±13.9μM. KD2,Ado is ~7 times larger than KD1,Ado, supporting the negative cooperative binding of AdoCbl to MMAB. The overall reverse rate constant of MMABS(kr1) and MMABD(kr1) are 3.7 s−1 and 5.0 s−1, respectively. kr2 is 1.35-times kr1, which suggests the dissociation processes are not the dominant contributors to the negative cooperativity. While the overall forward rate constant of MMABU1(kf1) and MMABS(kf2) are 0.66 s−1 and 0.12 s−1, respectively, kf1 is 5.5 times higher than kf2, which suggests the association process is the major factor that causes negative cooperativity. We also estimate KD1,OHCbl=15.0±5.0μM and KD2,OHCbl=189±111μM. KD2,OHCbl is ~13 times larger than KD1,OHCbl. It is important to note that the KD2,OHCbl value is associated with a substantial error because our experimental OHCbl concentrations, which went up to 80 μM, did not achieve full saturation of the second binding site.

sec.title: Extraction of kinetic rate constants for MMAB-OHCbl interactions
sec.p: To extract the kinetic parameters for MMAB-OHCbl interactions, we derived analytical dwell-time solutions to dissect kinetic rate constants for MMAB-OHCbl interactions based on the minimal kinetic model (Figure 6E).

The length of τHM (duration time in the FH state and entering the FM state) is determined by all the kinetic processes that depart from the FH state. Based on the submodel of HM (Figure S12A), we derived the analytical expression of the probability density function of dwell time, fHM(t). To solve fHM(t), we started with the analytical expression of the probabilities of finding the species MMABS,PS(t). We first focused on the steps that involve the transition PU1(t), PU3(t), and PS(t). The single-molecule rate equations for these steps are (Equation 42)dPU1(t)dt=k-1iPU3t-k1iPU1t, (Equation 43)dPU3(t)dt=k1iPU1t-k-1i+k1oPU3t, (Equation 44)dPS(t)dt=k1oPU3t.

With the initial condition PU3(0)=0,PS(0)=0,PU1(0)=1, we obtained the analytical solution of fHM(t): (Equation 45)fHM(t)=dPS(t)dt=k1oPU3(t)=k1ik1o2ae(b+a)t-e(b-a)t, where a=14k1i+k-1i+k1o2-k1ik1o and b=-12k1i+k-1i+k1o.

Using the same principle, we derived the analytical expression of the probability density function of dwell time, fMH(t) and fML(t), based on submodel Figure S12B with the single-molecule rate equations (Equation 46)dPU1(t)dt=kr1PS(t), (Equation 47)dPS(t)dt=-kf2o+kr1PS(t), (Equation 48)dPD(t)dt=kf2oPS(t).
With the initial condition PD(0)=0,PU(0)=0, and PS(0)=1, (Equation 49)fMH(t)=dPU1(t)dt=kr1e-kf2o+kr1t, (Equation 50)fML(t)=dPD(t)dt=kf2oe-kf2o+kr1t.

Lastly, we also derived the analytical expression of the probability density function of fLM(t) based on submodel Figure S12C with the single-molecule rate equations and boundary condition (Equation 51)dPD(t)dt=-kr2PDt, (Equation 52)fLMt=dPDtdt=kr2e-kr2t.

By globally fitting the PDFHM data of 10, 40, and 80 μM OHCbl (Figure S12D) with Equation 45, we got k1i=2.8±0.3s-1,k-1i=4.0±0.5s-1, and k1=0.28±0.05μM-1s-1. Globally fitting PDFMH and PDFML (Figure S12E) with Equations 49 and 50 reports kr1(OHCbI)=4.5±0.6s-1 and kf2OHCbl=0.019±0.011μM-1s-1. Globally fitting PDFLM (Figure S12F) with Equation 52 gave the values of kr2(OHCbI)=3.6±0.3s-1.

sec.title: Lead contact
sec.p: Further information and requests for resources and reagents should be directed to and will be fulfilled by the lead contact, Tai-Yen Chen (tchen37@central.uh.edu).

sec.title: Materials availability
sec.p: All strains are available from the lead contact upon request.

list-item.p: All original data and custom source code reported in this paper have been deposited in the Figshare repository and are publicly available under https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.28791878.v1. The MATLAB codes used for analysis were based on previously published work.24
Any additional information required to reanalyze the data reported in this paper is available from the lead contact upon request.

sec.title: Supplementary Material
sec.p: SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION
Supplemental information can be found online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.xcrp.2025.102768

caption.title: MMAB-catalyzed AdoCbl synthesis and transfer to MMUT
caption.p: MMAB catalyzes AdoCbl synthesis from cob(II)alamin using ATP (step 1). Without apo-MMUT, AdoCbl undergoes homolysis and oxidation being converted to OHCbl, which dissociates from MMAB (step 2). Alternatively, MMAB transfers AdoCbl to apo-MMUT, forming holo-MMUT (step 3), which catalyzes the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA, replenishing the TCA cycle (step 4). MMAB can bind a maximum of two cob(II)alamin molecules. Consecutive binding and catalytic steps are omitted for clarity. This process is part of a larger protein network that optimizes B12 synthesis, trafficking, and utilization.

caption.title: The generation of single-molecule relative fluorescence trajectory
caption.p: (A) Cobalamin absorption spectra overlaid with the Alexa 555 emission spectrum.
(B) Normalized fluorescence spectra of labeled MMAB in the solution with AdoCbl varying from 0 to 6 μM.
(C) Fluorescence micrograph of Alexa 555-labeled MMAB. The red, blue, and green curves mark the boundaries of the central, middle, and peripheral parts of the laser beam profile. Scale bar, 1 μm.
(D) Intensity trajectories of red, blue, and green boxes in (C).
(E) Normalizing (D) by the average intensity of each trajectory gives the corresponding single-molecule relative fluorescence (SRF) trajectories.
(F) Intensity trajectories of the red box in (C) at [AdoCbl] = 0 μM (red line) and 20 μM (blue line).
(G) The normalized SRF trajectories of (F).

caption.title: SRF states reveal various AdoCbl binding stoichiometries
caption.p: (A) Representative SRF trajectory (gray line) from a single MMAB molecule at varying [AdoCbl] overlaid with the HMM-inferred state transitions using ebFRET. The HMM fit is shown to illustrate state segmentation (blue, green, and red lines represent the FH,FM, and FL states, respectively), not to replicate all fluorescence fluctuations. THM,TMH, and TLM denote the dwell times for transitions between SRF states: from high to medium, medium to high, and low to medium, respectively.

(B) SRF intensity histogram generated from (A) (blue solid circle) and the global fitting results (black line). The relative populations of FH,FM, and FL are highlighted with blue, green, and red shades, respectively.
(C) Assignment of various AdoCbl binding geometries of MMAB to the three SRF states. MMABU,MMABS, and MMABD represent MMAB under unbound, singly bound, and doubly bound state, respectively.

caption.title: Microscopic dwell times inform a minimal kinetic model for MMAB-AdoCbl interactions
caption.p: (A) AdoCbl-dependent <τHM>-1 shows the average binding rate increases with AdoCbl concentrations varying from 0.5 μM to 60 μM.

(B) Dwell-time distributions PDFHM under low and high AdoCbl concentrations. The τHM exhibits a clear exponential rise-and-decay pattern at lower AdoCbl concentrations (<20 μM). Such a feature gradually transforms into a single-exponential decay when AdoCbl concentration increases over 40 μM.
(C) AdoCbl-dependent <τLM>-1 shows that the unbinding rate from MMABD is AdoCbl independent.
(D) Dwell-time distributions PDFLM. The distributions exhibit a simple exponential decay across all AdoCbl concentrations.
(E) AdoCbl-dependent <τMH>-1 and <τML>-1 show a similar dose dependence.
(F) The ratio of transition events between τML and τMH processes increases linearly with AdoCbl.

(G) Proposed kinetic model for MMAB-AdoCbl interactions. The overall process follows a sequential two-step binding scheme: an initial association event MMABU1→MMABs governed by the overall rate constant kf1, followed by a second association event MMABs→MMABD governed by kf2. The first association step is shown to be more complex and detailed in the shaded box, involving a required conformational gating step (MMABU1↔MMABU2 with k1i and k-1i) prior to the microscopic ligand association (k1).
Data in (A), (C), (E), and (F) are presented as mean ± SD.

caption.title: Kinetic parameters for MMAB-AdoCbl interactions
caption.p: (A) The minimal kinetic model associates different MMAB species to SRF states.

(B) Fitting the PDFLM (blue bar) by a single-exponential function (red curve) reports kr2. The AdoCbl independent fitted kr2 suggests AdoCbl unbinds from MMABD through single-step dissociation. Data are presented as mean ± SD.
(C) The global fitting of PDFLML and PDFLMH with fLML(τ) and fLMH(τ) reports kf2 and kr1.
(D) The extraction of k1i,k-1i, and k1 was achieved using SMIS. The simulated τHM distributions (bottom) satisfactorily describe the experimental data (top).

caption.title: Kinetic analysis of MMAB-OHCbl interactions
caption.p: (A) OHCbl-dependent SRF intensity histogram.

(B) OHCbl-dependent populations of FH (PH, blue open circles), FM (PM, green open circles), and FL(PL, red open circles) states derived from the SRF histogram. Data are presented as mean ± SD. Shaded areas depict the populations predicted by the kinetic model detailed in (E) using the globally fitted rate constants (Table 1).
(C) Assignment of all possible OHCbl binding configurations of MMAB (MMABU,MMABS, and MMABD) to the three SRF states.
(D) Experimental dwell-time distributions of τHM,τLM, and τML.

(E) Proposed kinetic model describing MMAB-OHCbl interactions. MMABU1,MMABS, and MMABD represent MMAB in the unbound, singly bound, and doubly bound states, respectively. MMABU1 needs to undergo a conformational transition to MMABU3 before binding the first equivalent of OHCbl.
Kinetic parameters for MMAB-B12 interactions

fn.label: a
fn.p: LB, lower bound; UB, upper bound.

list-item.p: Single-molecule analysis reveals conformation-gated AdoCbl binding to MMAB
Conformational gating explains negative cooperativity in AdoCbl binding
Dissociation from MMAB is unimolecular and concentration independent
Single-molecule approach offers platform for probing cofactor interactions
